title: Best bike chain cleaners 2025 reviewed: Degreasers and drivetrain cleaners
content:
Cyclist
Best bike chain cleaners 2025 reviewed: Degreasers and drivetrain cleaners

Whether you’re brand new to bike maintenance or have a full-blown home workshop with every tool under the sun, investing in one of the best chain cleaners is crucial for keeping your drivetrain clean. Chain degreasers are liquid magic. They strip oil and gunk from your bike’s chain, cassette and jockey wheels, not only to keep them running smoothly, but to make them last longer as well.

There are lots of degreasers on the market, from powerful solvents to easy-spray foam and water-based solutions, all promising the same results via different methods. But don’t be overwhelmed by the choice. All the degreasers we’ve recommended below will do the job; they just work in different ways and some might be more suitable than others, depending on your individual circumstances.

For this guide, we teamed up with Wobbly Wheel Cyclery in Sheffield to access lots of bikes with dirty chains – the more grime the better! For each chain cleaned, we coated it in degreaser, agitated it with the same stiff bristle brush, then rinsed or wiped it clean with either a dry rag or wet sponge, as per the manufacturer’s instructions. We didn’t use a chain cleaning tool, partly to emulate the minimal setup that most cyclists will have at home, and this way it was easier to compare like-for-like performance against solvent degreasers that don’t require any scrubbing.

Read on for our roundup of the best chain degreasers for cyclists. If you need to brush up on the basics first, check our handy bike maintenance guides. We can walk you through how to clean your bike chain, step by step, or you can potentially save yourself some wasted time by first familiarising yourself with how to check your bike’s chain for wear. Once your chain’s clean, you’ll need to re-lube it properly, so don’t miss our roundup of the best bike chain lube too.

Best bike chain degreasers at a glance

  1. Muc-off Drivetrain Cleaner — RRP from £20.00
  2. Juice Lubes Dirt Juice No Nonsense Chain Cleaner — RRP £14.99
  3. Gtechniq Drivetrain Degreaser — RRP from £19.99
  4. Finish Line Speed Degreaser — RRP £14.00
  5. Peaty’s Foaming Drivetrain Degreaser — RRP from £13.99
  6. Weldtite Thunder Foam Chain Degreaser — RRP £10.99
  7. Fenwicks Foaming Chain Cleaner — RRP from £7.00
  8. Silca Ultimate Brake + Drivetrain Cleaner — RRP £30.00

Why can you trust Cyclist‘s advice?

Our team has spent years testing cleaning products across all kinds of bikes, from commuters and road bikes, to gravel bikes and mountain bikes. We don’t just look at how well a product cuts through grime, we also assess how easy it is to use, whether it offers real value for money, and how it fits into a real-world maintenance routine. Whether we’re testing degreasers on mucky winter drivetrains or dusty summer chains, our advice is based on hands-on experience.

Best bike chain degreasers 2025

Muc-Off Bio Drivetrain Cleaner

RRP from £20.00 | View offer

  • Biodegradable and safe on all bike materials
  • Effective at shifting grime with minimal scrubbing
  • Ready-to-use spray with convenient trigger bottle

Muc-Off’s Bio Drivetrain Cleaner is a biodegradable, water-based solution that’s ready to use straight from the bottle. It comes with a trigger spray and is safe on all materials including rubber, plastic and anodised metals, so there’s no risk to your components.

It works fast: just spray generously over the chain, cassette and derailleur, leave it for a minute, then agitate with a brush or chain cleaning tool. In testing, it shifted a significant amount of grime with minimal effort, though it didn’t leave the chain spotless. A quick rinse with water and a sponge helped reveal much cleaner metal underneath.

One drawback is the spray pattern: it’s wide and tends to overshoot, making it messy and a little wasteful, especially in tight spaces. That said, a little goes a long way. The strong chemical smell is another thing to consider: it’s best used outside or in well-ventilated areas. Still, for overall cleaning power and ease of use, it’s a solid choice.

Verdict: A household name for a reason, Muc-Off’s powerful, biodegradable water-based degreaser is easy to use and delivers strong results, though its wide spray can be wasteful and smelly.

The dos and don’ts of winter bike maintenance

Juice Lubes Dirt Juice No Nonsense Chain Cleaner

RRP £14.99 | View offer

  • Biodegradable and safe for all bike components
  • Fresh, low-odour formula suitable for indoor use
  • Clings well and lifts grime quickly

Juice Lubes Dirt Juice is a biodegradable, water-based degreaser that performs well and offers good value for money. It’s safe for use on carbon fibre, metals, rubber, plastic and seals, and designed to clean all bike types. While it’s a drivetrain-specific cleaner, the brand does state that it can be used on any other parts of the bike that are caked with grease and grime.

Used straight from the bottle and sprayed directly onto the chain, it clings well and starts breaking down grime almost instantly. In testing, a few squirts followed by a quick scrub with a stiff brush and rinse with a wet sponge was enough to lift stubborn gunk with ease. It felt slightly faster-acting than the Muc-Off degreaser, with similarly impressive results.

One drawback is that the wide spray pattern results in some product waste, but like others we had on test, a little goes a long way. Of all the degreasers listed here, this one has the most pleasant odour, and was actually surprisingly fresh and fruity, so it would be a great choice if you’re doing your bike maintenance indoors with minimal ventilation.

Verdict: Dirt Juice lives up to its name, with fast-acting and minimal effort cleaning, all while smelling good.

Gtechniq Drivetrain Degreaser

RRP from £19.99 | View offer

  • Biodegradable and safe for all bikes, including e-bikes
  • Excellent cleaning performance with minimal scrubbing
  • Low odour, ideal for indoor use

Gtechniq’s Drivetrain Degreaser is a water-based, biodegradable formula that’s safe for all bikes, including e-bikes. It has a very mild scent, with just a faint hint of solvent, but it’s nothing overpowering. This makes it a good option for working indoors.

In testing, we found it worked incredibly well with a simple squirt-brush-rinse routine. You apply it straight to your chain, cassette or derailleur, agitate it gently with a soft-bristled brush, and then rinse with a sponge or low-pressure hose. Grime came off easily after a light scrub with a brush and rinse with a sponge, producing visibly clean results without much elbow grease. 

One downside is the spray mechanism itself: like the other water-based products listed here, it delivers a wide fan of spray, which can be quite wasteful. Still, the efficiency of the actual cleaning power makes up for this.

Verdict: A highly effective, mild-scented cleaner that tackles grime with minimal elbow grease, but suffers from an overly wide spray pattern that wastes product.

Finish Line Speed Degreaser

RRP £14.00 | View offer

  • No water or brushes needed for use
  • Precision straw for targeted application
  • Works quickly with minimal mess

Finish Line Speed Degreaser is a solvent-based spray designed to be convenient and quick to use (hence the name). It comes with a precision straw for targeted application, helping to reduce waste, which is a nice touch for a powerful aerosol cleaner.

Designed to work without brushes or rinsing, it’s ideal if you just need a quick spruce-up or regular low-effort maintenance. In testing, it performed best as a two-step process: spray, wipe, then spray again. The first pass didn’t shift much on really dirty chains, but the second application made oil and grime disintegrate like magic.

With a strong, fumy solvent smell, it’s definitely not one for enclosed spaces, and we’d recommend using it outside if the weather allows. But for lazy or time-poor mechanics, its minimal-effort approach makes it a solid grab-and-go degreaser for surface level cleaning.

Verdict: A great grab-and-go degreaser for the lazy mechanic or anyone short on time and tools. Fast-acting aerosol for surface-level cleaning, but less suitable for deep cleans or enclosed spaces.

Peaty’s Foaming Drivetrain Degreaser

RRP from £13.99 | View offer

  • Thick foam clings to drivetrain for continuous cleaning
  • Biodegradable formula and refills available
  • Affordable option for those on a budget

Peaty’s Foaming Drivetrain Degreaser takes a different approach, spraying out as a thick foam that clings to your drivetrain rather than dripping off. It’s designed to dissolve grime before lifting it away, and in theory, that makes for less mess and more effective cleaning.

In practice, it needs a generous coating to be effective on baked-on grime, and the high-pressure spray means a fair bit goes astray. Unlike other foaming cleaners with narrow precision nozzles, the Peaty’s degreaser has a trigger spray nozzle similar to the water-based products. While it doesn’t spray in a wide fan, it’s neither controlled nor precise.

With the really dirty chains, after letting it dwell and giving it a scrub, we found one application wasn’t quite enough, and a second round was needed to match the first-time results of some other products on test. It’s also very fumy, with a strong solvent smell that’s not great for indoor use.

It gets bonus points for not only being biodegradable but also refillable, however performance-wise it’s less convincing than others we reviewed. It gets the job done eventually, but uses more product and takes more effort than others here. Still, for the price, it’s a good option if you’re on a tight budget.

Verdict: Budget-friendly and refillable, Peaty’s Foaming Drivetrain Degreaser gets the job done eventually, and well, but requires more time and product than others if you’ve accumulated a lot of grease.

Weldtite Thunder Foam Chain Degreaser

RRP £10.99 | View offer

  • Expanding foam breaks down grime without water
  • Budget-friendly and disc brake-safe
  • Pleasant citrus scent with no harsh solvent smell

Weldtite’s Thunder Foam is a budget-friendly, disc- and carbon-safe aerosol degreaser that sprays on with the consistency of shaving foam: thick, dense and fast-expanding. It’s designed to cling to your chain and break down built-up gunk, and pull the dirt away without water. This makes it ideal for quick, tool-free cleaning for the lazy mechanic.

Used carefully, it’s really effective. After a few minutes, wiping it with a rag leaves the chain looking noticeably cleaner. That said, it’s easy to overdo it. Because the foam expands quickly it can be a bit unruly if you’re too enthusiastic, with large blobs dropping off and wasting product. For the best results, apply in short, precise bursts along individual chain links, to keep the flow of foam controlled and the chain coated.

Performance is decent: it lifts surface grime well, and leaves a pleasantly fresh citrus scent in its wake. Heavier buildup will need a bit more attention, but used carefully, and paired with a brush, it can deliver solid results on really grimy chains without the solvent stink.

Verdict: A foaming aerosol degreaser with solid performance and great value, but you need a careful hand to control the flow of foam and avoid wasting product.

Fenwicks Foaming Chain Cleaner

RRP from £7.00 | View offer

  • Precision nozzle reduces waste and mess
  • Solvent-free and safe for all materials
  • Great for quick, fuss-free maintenance

Fenwicks’ Foaming Chain Cleaner is a gentle, solvent-free degreaser that’s designed to be easy to use with minimal mess. It dispenses a dense, shaving foam-like consistency through a thin precision nozzle, which makes for a controlled application. Unlike some sprays that blast out uncontrollably, this one lets you slowly layer the foam along the chain in a neat line, reducing waste and overspray. Of all the foaming cleaners, this is the easiest to control.

It sits well on the chain without dripping off, which is great for indoor use or quick top-up cleans. There’s no harsh smell either, just a faint scent that’s barely noticeable. The foam is designed to be left for a couple of minutes before agitating it with a brush, and while Fenwicks recommends using it with its chain cleaning sponge, a standard brush does the job just fine.

It’s very user-friendly and gentle enough for all bike materials, but it’s less effective on stubborn grime. After one pass, a fair bit of dirt was left behind, even with brushing. A second application brought much better results, but that means using more product than you might expect, so while it’s cheap, it doesn’t go far if your drivetrain is really filthy. That said, if you keep on top of maintenance, it’s a handy, fuss-free option.

Verdict: A gentle foam cleaner that’s easier to apply carefully and control in order to avoid waste. Not ideal for thick, caked-on gunk, but to keep your chain running smoothly between deep cleans, it’s a winner.

Silca Ultimate Brake + Drivetrain Cleaner

RRP £30.00 | View offer

  • Plant-based, biodegradable and non-toxic
  • pH-balanced and disc brake safe
  • Visual oxidation effect shows it’s working

Positioning itself at the luxury end of the maintenance spectrum is Silca’s Ultimate Brake + Drivetrain Cleaner, a pH-balanced, non-toxic degreaser that’s part of the brand’s premium Bike Spa system. With a plant-based, biodegradable formula free from phosphates and acids, it’s designed to offer serious cleaning power without the environmental baggage of harsher solvents.

In practice, it does a solid job of cutting through grime. It shifts dirt effectively, though like most water-based cleaners, it struggles slightly with caked-on grease and might leave behind some residue on especially filthy drivetrains. That said, if you’re spending the money on Silca degreaser, you’re probably precious about your bike and keeping it clean already. 

The degreaser oxidises on contact with metal, turning a deep red: a dramatic visual touch that some folks might appreciate. Unfortunately like many of the other cleaners on this list, application is a stumbling point. The standard spray nozzle emits a wide mist that’s hard to control. It’s great for brakes, cassettes and derailleurs, but still likely to result in wasted product, and for a cleaner priced at £30 for just under half a litre, you don’t really want it to end up on the floor.

Scent-wise, Silca promises cinnamon, but the reality is… odd. Not enough to clear the room, but definitely best used outdoors or in a well-ventilated area, unless you happen to like it.

Verdict: Eco-friendly degreaser that works incredibly well with minimal fuss. It’s pricey, but premium, though the wasteful application is a bit of a put off if you want value for your money.

  • Buy now from Tredz (£36)

How to choose from the best chain degreasers for cyclists

Water-based, solvent or foaming?

There are generally three types of chain degreaser: Water-based, solvent and foaming.

  • Water-based degreasers are biodegradable, generally safer for indoor use, and often require a rinse with water afterwards. 
  • Solvent-based degreasers tend to work faster and require less elbow grease, but they can be harsh, smelly, and less environmentally friendly. 
  • Foaming degreasers strike a balance between the other two. They cling well to components, but often need a second application for deep cleaning.

Application and waste

Most chain cleaners come in spray bottles or aerosols. Trigger sprays tend to emit a wide fan of spray, which can lead to wasted product on the floor. Aerosols with straw applicators are more precise, but often come with environmental trade-offs, plus they often have a strong smell and can fill a workshop with fumes if you use a lot without good ventilation. Foam-based options tend to be neater, but if overapplied, they can also be wasteful. Whichever format you choose, applying the degreaser directly to the chain in short, controlled bursts will help to reduce waste and give you more value for your money.

Environmental impact

Biodegradable formulas are increasingly becoming the norm now, and they’re generally safe to rinse off into drains. However, solvent-based aerosols often contain VOCs (volatile organic compounds), which are less environmentally-friendly and should be used sparingly and outdoors. If you’re keen to reduce your environmental footprint, opt for a brand that offers refills and concentrated formulas that you can dilute and use for longer.

Value for money

More expensive doesn’t always mean better. Some premium degreasers offer luxury packaging or subtle scent gimmicks, but perform similarly to cheaper, biodegradable options. What matters most is how dirty your drivetrain gets, how frequently you clean it, and whether you prioritise convenience, potency, or environmental impact. A well-priced degreaser that gets the job done without requiring loads of product (or waste) offers the best long-term value for money.

Can I clean my chain with WD40?

Not ideally, but you can if you wish. While WD40 does have degreasing properties, the standard multi-use version is more of a water dispersant and light lubricant, so it’s not designed to cut through heavy grime. There is a specific WD40 Bike Degreaser, which would be more appropriate, but regular WD40 won’t match the cleaning power of purpose-built chain degreasers.

Can I clean my chain with washing up liquid?

Washing up liquid can work in a pinch, but again it’s not ideal. It’s designed to break down food grease, not drivetrain gunk, and may struggle with stubborn grime. It also doesn’t rinse away chain oil properly and could leave a residue. If you do use it, be sure to rinse and wipe it thoroughly to remove as much residue as possible, and re-lube your chain afterwards. For regular maintenance, dedicated bike chain degreasers are far more effective.

How often should I degrease my drivetrain?

It depends on your riding conditions and mileage. As a general rule, try to clean your chain and drivetrain every 100-200km if you’re riding in wet or muddy conditions, or every 300-500km in dry weather. If your chain looks black and sticky or makes noise while you pedal, it’s definitely time for a clean. Check out our guide to how to clean your bike chain for a step-by-step walk through.

Do I need a chain cleaning tool or is a brush enough?

A stiff-bristled brush is usually enough for most cleans, but chain-specific tools can make the job quicker and less messy, especially if you clean frequently, and have multiple bikes to maintain. Foam-based or thick degreasers work well with a brush, while thin liquids may benefit from a tool to capture and recycle the cleaner. This can be a great way to reduce the amount of degreaser that ends up on the floor as well, and make the product go further.

Do I need to re-lube the chain after cleaning?

Yes. Degreasers strip away all lubricant as well as dirt. After cleaning and drying your chain, always apply fresh chain lube to prevent your chain from rusting and keep it running smoothly for longer. Be sure to check out our guide to the best bike chain lube if you need to stock up.

Can I use drivetrain degreasers on other parts of the bike?

Many drivetrain degreasers are safe for use on other metal components, including derailleurs and cassettes. Some are even suitable for frame and brake cleaning as is, while others will stipulate that you should dilute the formula first. Always check the label, though. Certain formulas might be too harsh for delicate components or finishes.

What’s the difference between a degreaser and a general bike cleaner?

Degreasers are formulated to cut through oil, grease and grime, particularly on the drivetrain, while general bike cleaners are milder and better suited to removing dust, dirt and road grime from the frame, wheels and other components. Using a drivetrain cleaner on your frame would be overkill, while using a frame cleaner on your chain won’t get it properly clean. As we mentioned above, there’s also a risk of using harsh solvents on delicate bike parts, so it’s always best to check the label and use a product the way the manufacturers intended.

author: Pnorman
